content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"          xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"          xmlns:silvanews="http://infrae.com/namespaces/silvanews"          xmlns:rss="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/">   <rss:channel rdf:about="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/events">     <rss:title>Programme</rss:title>     <rss:link>http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/events/rss</rss:link>     <rss:description>UCL Centre for Digital Humanities, bringing together disparate expertise in computing and arts, heritage, and cultural research at UCL.</rss:description>     <dc:creator>Rudolf Ammann</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2010-11-26T12:27:33Z</dc:date>          <rss:items>       <rdf:Seq>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/The-Antikythera-Mechanism"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/Reassembling-the-Republic-of-Letters"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/urban-spaces-via-GPS"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/susanhockey"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/the-transcriptorium-project"/>       </rdf:Seq>     </rss:items>   </rss:channel>        <rss:item rdf:about="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/The-Antikythera-Mechanism">       <rss:title>The Antikythera Mechanism: A Personal Journey of Discovery</rss:title>       <rss:link>http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/The-Antikythera-Mechanism</rss:link>       <rss:description>      The Antikythera Mechanism is an ancient Greek astronomical calculating machine of remarkable sophistication. As part of an international team of scientists, Dr Tony Freeth has been a central part of research on the Antikythera Mechanism over the last fifteen years. It has been an extraordinary journey of discovery, which has led to a revolution in our understanding of the device. It is a landmark in the history of science and technology and one of the true wonders of the ancient world.</rss:description>              <dc:creator>Sarah Davenport</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2015-02-13T11:03:50Z</dc:date>       <silvanews:location>G31, Foster Court, UCL</silvanews:location>       <silvanews:start_datetime>2015-03-25T17:30:00Z</silvanews:start_datetime>                   </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/Reassembling-the-Republic-of-Letters">       <rss:title>Networking to the fourth power: Reassembling the Republic of Letters, 1500-1800</rss:title>       <rss:link>http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/Reassembling-the-Republic-of-Letters</rss:link>       <rss:description>          Between 1500 and 1800, the development of increasingly affordable, reliable, and accessible postal systems allowed scholars to scatter correspondence across and beyond Europe.\ufffd\ufffd This epistolary exchange knit together the self-styled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdrepublic of letters\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, an international, knowledge-based civil society central to that era\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds intellectual breakthroughs and formative for many of modern Europe\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds values and institutions. Despite its importance, the republic of letters remains poorly integrated into early modern European intellectual history, and this primarily for one simple reason: its core practice of creating communities by dispersing archives of manuscripts has posed insuperable difficulties to subsequent generations of historians attempting to reconstruct the very documents which established this community.\ufffd\ufffd The ongoing revolution in digital communication provides, for the first time, an adequate medium for reassembling the material dispersed by the earlier revolution in postal communication; but before this potential can be realized we need, not merely to adapt the technology to the task, but also to adapt our working methods and scholarly cultures to the technology. More specifically, we need (1) to create an interdisciplinary network of archivists, librarians, IT systems developers, experts in communication and design, educationalists, and scholars from many different fields (2) to design the networking infrastructure and scholarly practices needed (3) to support an international scholarly community devoted (4) to piecing back together the scattered documentation of the international republic of letters.\ufffd\ufffd In other words, we need a network to design a network to support a network reconstructing networks: networking to the fourth power.\ufffd\ufffd</rss:description>              <dc:creator>Sarah Davenport</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2015-03-02T15:21:50Z</dc:date>       <silvanews:location>G31, Foster Court</silvanews:location>       <silvanews:start_datetime>2015-05-06T16:30:00Z</silvanews:start_datetime>                   </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/urban-spaces-via-GPS">       <rss:title>Embodiments, Subjectivities and Reconfigurations of Urban Spaces via GPS Mobile Applications: Driving/Guiding</rss:title>       <rss:link>http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/urban-spaces-via-GPS</rss:link>       <rss:description>                  In his research,  Regner Ramos  explores the relationship between bodies, urban space and mobile technologies by studying the affectional and spatial properties of three GPS-based mobile applications\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdGrindr, Mappiness and Waze. Guided by cyberfeminist theories, he approaches these apps as a series of material objects, particularly when addressing the physical and spatial properties of the screen/interface; through interface and performance the apps create a sense of othering and difference, as theorised by Donna Haraway, Rosie Braidotti and Katherine Hayles. Thus, his dissertation seeks to address and understand the ways in which GPS apps create new spatiotemporal relations for bodies, as well as how these relations are made visible/mobilised by the interfaces\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd spatial and urban representations.</rss:description>              <dc:creator>Sarah Davenport</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2015-03-02T15:39:53Z</dc:date>       <silvanews:location>G31, Foster Court</silvanews:location>       <silvanews:start_datetime>2015-05-20T16:30:00Z</silvanews:start_datetime>                   </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/susanhockey">       <rss:title>Digital Humanities: Perspectives on Past, Present and Future</rss:title>       <rss:link>http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/susanhockey</rss:link>       <rss:description>  In our first installment of  The Susan Hockey Lecture  series, Professor Susan Hockey discusses the trajectory of digital humanities from its many years on the fringes to its current position at the centre of the humanities scholarly arena, and its future challenges.</rss:description>              <dc:creator>Sarah Davenport</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2015-02-13T15:34:03Z</dc:date>       <silvanews:location>Sir Ambrose Fleming Lecture Theatre, Roberts Building, UCL</silvanews:location>       <silvanews:start_datetime>2015-05-27T17:00:00Z</silvanews:start_datetime>                   </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/the-transcriptorium-project">       <rss:title>Interactive Handwritten Text Recognition and Indexing of Historical Documents: the tranScriptorium project</rss:title>       <rss:link>http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dh/events/archive/the-transcriptorium-project</rss:link>       <rss:description>            In this talk,  Enrique Vidal  and  Joan Andreu Sanchez  from the  Pattern Recognition and Human Language Technology Research Center  (Universidad Politecnica de Valencia) will talk about the  Transcriptorium project ,\ufffd\ufffdwhich aims to develop innovative, efficient and cost-effective solutions for the indexing, search and full transcription of historical handwritten document images, using modern, holistic Handwritten Text Recognition (HTR) technology. tranScriptorium will turn HTR into a mature technology by addressing the following objectives:\ufffd\ufffd</rss:description>              <dc:creator>Sarah Davenport</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2015-03-06T16:54:04Z</dc:date>       <silvanews:location>G24, Arts and Humanities Common Room, Foster Court</silvanews:location>       <silvanews:start_datetime>2015-06-01T16:30:00Z</silvanews:start_datetime>                   </rss:item>    </rdf:RDF>
